noun.description: A person initiated into mysteries, especially religious mysteries.

origin: Late 17th century; earliest use found in Joseph Glanvill (1636–1680), Church of England clergyman. From classical Latin mystēs or its etymon ancient Greek μύστης initiate from the base of μύειν to close + -της, suffix forming agent nouns; the primary sense is probably person vowed to keep silence. Compare ancient Greek μυεῖν to initiate into mysteries.
